configurations.description: The administrative port the client should connect to.
configurations.name: adminPort

configurations.description: Glassfish Admin Server (DAS) host address.
configurations.name: adminHost

configurations.description: Use SSL for communicating with the admin server.
configurations.name: adminHttps

configurations.description: The name of the admin user of your DAS. If omitted, no authentication will be used to access the DAS. This case you must have empty password for your admin user.
configurations.name: adminUser

configurations.description: The password of the admin user of your DAS. Canot be omitted if you declare the admin user. If no authentication will be used to access the DAS you must have empty password for your admin user.
configurations.name: adminPassword

configurations.description: Specifies the target to which you are deploying. We use the “target” as property key with the same semantics as the standard GlassFish utilities do.
configurations.name: target

configurations.description: A comma-separated list of library JAR files. Specify the library JAR  files by their relative or absolute paths. Specify relative paths relative to domain-dir/lib/applibs. The libraries are made available to the application in the order specified. For more detail, please refer to GlassFish Server 3.1 Administration Guide.
configurations.name: libraries

configurations.description: Optional keyword-value pairs  that  specify  additional properties for the deployment. The available properties are determined by the implementation of the  component that is being deployed. For more detail, please refer to GlassFish Server 3.1 Administration Guide.
configurations.name: properties

configurations.description: The packaging archive type of the component that is being deployed. Only valid value is: osgi meaning that the component is package is an OSGi Alliance bundle. The type option is optional. If the component is packaged as a regular archive, omit this option. For more detail, please refer to OSGi Application Development using GlassFish Server
configurations.name: type

configurations.description: The HTTP port the server should bind to.
configurations.name: bindHttpPort

configurations.description: The instanceRoot to use for booting the server. If it does not exist, a default structure will be created.
configurations.name: instanceRoot

configurations.description: The installRoot to use for booting the server. If it does not exist, a default structure will be created.
configurations.name: installRoot

configurations.description: The relative or absolute path to the domain.xml file that will be used to configure the instance. If absent, the default domain.xml configuration will be used.
configurations.name: configurationXml

configurations.description: If true deployment changes are not written to the configuration and persisted.
configurations.name: configurationReadOnly

configurations.description: The relative or absolute path to the sun-resources.xml file that will be used to add resources to the instance using the add-resources asadmin command.
configurations.name: sunResourcesXml

configurations.description: The HTTP port the server should bind to.
configurations.name: bindHttpPort

configurations.description: The host the server should be run on.
configurations.name: bindAddress

configurations.description: Activates the Jetty plus configuration to support JNDI resources (requires jetty-plus and jetty-naming artifacts on the classpath).
configurations.name: jettyPlus

configurations.description: Specify your own Jetty configuration classes as a comma separated list.
configurations.name: configurationClasses

configurations.name: managementAddress

configurations.name: managementPort

configurations.description: The ip address of the running server instances management interface
configurations.name: managementAddress

configurations.description: The management port for deployment
configurations.name: managementPort

configurations.description: Activate ConversationScope between @Test methods. Use this to simulate Weld Servlet HTTP Conversation scope support.
configurations.name: enableConversationScope

configurations.description: The listen address, port and protocol of the WebLogic domain's Administration Server.
configurations.name: adminUrl

configurations.description: The protocol used to connect to the Administration Server when running the weblogic.Deployer command. This is optional, for this is deduced from the adminUrl property
configurations.name: adminProtocol

configurations.description: The listen address of the Administration Server; weblogic.Deployer will connect to the Administration Server bound to this address. This is optional, for this is deduced from the adminUrl property.
configurations.name: adminListenAddress

configurations.description: The port on which the Administration Server listens for admin traffic. weblogic.Deployer will connect to the Administration Server at this port. This is optional, for this is deduced from the adminUrl property.
configurations.name: adminListenPort

configurations.description: The name of the WebLogic Server user to use for authentication. Any user specified here, should belong to the Deployers group.
configurations.name: adminUserName

configurations.description: The password of the WebLogic Server user, to use for authentication.
configurations.name: adminPassword

configurations.description: The location of the WebLogic Server installation.
configurations.name: wlsHome

configurations.description: The target for the deployment. This is either an individual Server or a cluster within the WebLogic domain.
configurations.name: target

configurations.description: The location of the weblogic.jar file within the WebLogic Server installation. The location is typically inferred from the wlsHome property, but this can be specified explicitly.
configurations.name: weblogicJarPath

configurations.description: The location of the wljmxclient.jar file within the WebLogic Server installtion. Like the weblogicJarPath property, this one is typically inferred from the wlsHome property, but can be set explicitly.
configurations.name: jmxLibPath

configurations.description: The protocol to use, to connect to the WebLogic Domain Runtime MBean Server. If the value is not specified, it will be derived from the adminUrl property.
configurations.name: jmxProtocol

configurations.description: The hostname or IP address to connect to, when creating a connection to the WebLogic Domain Runtime MBean Server. If the value is not specified, it will be derived from the adminUrl property.
configurations.name: jmxHost

configurations.description: The port on the jmxHost to connect to, when creating a connection to the WebLogic Domain Runtime MBean Server. If the value is not specified, it will be derived from the adminUrl property.
configurations.name: jmxPort

configurations.description: Specifies whether the weblogic.Deployer command and the JMX client should use the WebLogic Demonstration Trust Store when connecting to the Domain Administration Server on a SSL port.
configurations.name: useDemoTrust

configurations.description: Specifies whether the weblogic.Deployer command and the JMX client should use the Trust Store of the JRE when connecting to the Domain Administration Server on a SSL port.
configurations.name: useJavaStandardTrust

configurations.description: pecifies whether the weblogic.Deployer command and the JMX client should use a Custom Trust Store when connecting to the Domain Administration Server on a SSL port.
configurations.name: useCustomTrust

configurations.description: The Java Runtime Environment to use for launching the weblogic.Deployer command.
configurations.name: javaHome

configurations.description: The location of the truststore to use when connecting to an Administration Server on a SSL channel.
configurations.name: trustStoreLocation

configurations.description: The password used to protect the truststore. Usually, one need not specify a password, as the trust store entries (in a JKS file) can be read without a password.
configurations.name: trustStorePassword

configurations.description: Your Openshift domain name
configurations.name: namespace

configurations.description: Openshift application name
configurations.name: application

configurations.description: The sshUserName can be found in the Repository URL in the Express Console, e.g. ssh:// 4348a6ba9d3943e6a64e0a1607b37bd5 @test-ikecloud.rhcloud.com/~/git/test.git/
configurations.name: sshUserName

configurations.description: Openshift password
configurations.name: passphrase

configurations.description: Openshift login
configurations.name: login
